title: 3 Quick Ways to Insert a File into a Word Document

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . You'll see this tab in the menu bar at the top of your document. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you don't already have a document opened in Microsoft Word , do so now.

steps.title: Click Object.
steps.content: Click Object . You can find this in the Text section, underneath Date & Time . If your document window isn't maximized, you might not see a text label next to the Object icon. It looks like a blank page with a square window superimposed on it. A new window will open.

steps.title: Click Create from File.
steps.content: Click Create from File . This is the second tab at the top. If you're using a Mac, you'll see a Create from File button on the bottom left side of the window. Click it and skip to Step 5.

steps.title: Click Browse.
steps.content: Click Browse . You can find this on the right of the File name field. A pop-up window will open

steps.title: Select your file and click Insert.
steps.content: Select your file and click Insert . Use the window to find the file you want to insert into the Word document. You can also double-click the file to add it. If you're using Word for Mac, click the Show Options button before you click Insert . Use this menu to choose whether you want the file to show up as an embedded link or clickable icon that will open the file separately instead of inserting it directly into your document. In Word for Mac, clicking Insert will immediately insert the file (or the link or icon, depending on the options you chose in the Show Options menu). You can skip the following two steps.

steps.title: Check the box for "Display as icon".
steps.content: Check the box for "Display as icon". The file will show up in the document as an embedded icon, which can be clicked to be redirected to the actual file. If you want to share a link for the file, check the box for Link to file instead.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . The file will be inserted.

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This tab is in the menu bar at the top of your document. Use this method to insert the content of another Word document into this new document. You can insert contents of a PDF, but the content may not look exactly like how it does in the original PDF. steps.title: Click the down-arrow next to "Object".
steps.content: Click the down-arrow next to "Object". You can find this in the Text section, underneath Date & Time . A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Click Text from File….
steps.content: Click Text from File… . This is the second option. A new window will open.

steps.title: Select your file and click Insert.
steps.content: Select your file and click Insert . Use the window to find the document you want to insert into the Word document. The document will be added. You can also double-click the document to add it. If you're inserting a PDF file, you'll need to click OK to confirm.

steps.title: Click where you want to insert the picture.
steps.content: Click where you want to insert the picture . The cursor should be blinking in the location.

steps.title: Click the Insert tab.
steps.content: Click the Insert tab. It's at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click Pictures.
steps.content: Click Pictures . This is in the Illustrations section.

steps.title: Click This Device….
steps.content: Click This Device… . This is the first option. In some versions of Word, like Word for Mac, this option may be called Picture from File instead. If you want to browse through Microsoft's library, you can select Stock Images or Online Pictures .

steps.title: Select the file to insert.
steps.content: Select the file to insert. Use the window to find the file you want to insert into the Word document.

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . The picture will be inserted into your Word document.
